awd_abstract_narration:
This project will provide 30 scholarships annually to financially needy, academically talented students through the Cyber Generation Tech Stars scholarship program. It will assist promising students who choose to major in one of the three related associate degree STEM programs within Florence-Darlington Technical College's division of Technical and General Education: Computer Technology/Network Systems Management, Industrial Technology, or Engineering Technology. Students will be expected to earn an Associate Degree and then to enter the workforce or transfer to continue their education at a baccalaureate degree-granting institution. The project builds upon work from a prior S-STEM grant, which established a comprehensive student support structure that has proven successful in increasing retention and success among underrepresented groups in STEM fields. Student support strategies include innovative loan-to-own technology support, social media and events that support cohesive cohorts, and mobile technology messages from the industry to advance students' knowledge and understanding of STEM careers and the modern workplace.

Results from the project could be informative for the larger academic community on student success and have a potentially transformative effect on the nation's open-door two-year technical and community colleges. Targeted outreach activities and role model Career Ambassadors will encourage females and minorities to consider careers in STEM disciplines. The SC ATE Center of Excellence, a NSF/ATE National Resource Center, will facilitate the dissemination of project results.

por.por_cntn:
The four-year Cyber Generation Tech Stars project (DUE# 1259402) provided innovative scholarships to promising students who choose to major in one of three related associate degree STEM programs within the division of Technical and General Education at Florence-Darlington Technical College, SC: Computer Technology/Network Systems Management, Industrial Technology, or Engineering Technology.  In addition to financial support for tuition, fees, and books, scholarship recipients were provided with essential technology for their majors: a powerful laptop computer with discipline-specific software plus a MiFi hotspot or an automotive diagnostic tool.

The project engaged and supported 174 STEM students called Tech Stars. These scholars had an overall retention rate of 75% and graduation rate of 80%.  Ninety-three percent or more earned automatic scholarship renewal each year by completing required curriculum courses for on-time graduation, maintaining high grades, and adhering to the college Code of Conduct throughout the previous academic year.  The assurance of scholarship renewal if Tech Stars criteria were met served as an effective retention strategy.  

The technology-support strategy helped close a persistent digital divide among those receiving scholarships in the rural Florence-Darlington Technical College service region that serves predominantly African American (~50%) and first generation (65%) students.  Any digital divide among selected scholarship recipients was effectively closed with all Tech Stars being equally equipped with loan-to-own technology tools and internet access essential for academic success.  Remaining scholarship-eligible from year to year allowed students to retain the loaned technology devise(s) until graduation when ownership of the technology devices was transferred to the graduate.   A unique, variable-amount scholarship award strategy individually customized scholarships for students by coordinating with other financial aid and then closing any remaining financial gap by semester.  Providing scholarship support in the amount needed, when needed, resulted in an efficient use of scholarship funds that in enabled the number of scholarships that were awarded to increase from the planned 120 to 174 actually awarded.  The project provided scholars with a clear, flexible, and well-supported pathway to on-time, often debt-free, graduation. Strategies supported diverse students, improved teacher/student interaction, provided workforce internships and transfer preparedness, and closed the digital divide experienced by the more economically challenged scholars. The project also created paid internship opportunities with local industries, opportunities for six Tech Stars to attend professional conferences, payment for relevant industry-recognized certification exams, and a series of 10 industry-driven lunch-and-learn sessions. Almost all Tech Stars who were interns are now working for their industry internship sponsors.

The loan-to-own technology support provided to Tech Stars was the greatest factor in high retention and graduation rates among scholars. A Women and Minorities in Technology program launched by the project assisted in recruiting and retaining underrepresented students in the targeted majors by assisting participants in making post associate degree career decisions, identifying role models, and creating study groups.  

In addition to the student impacts, the team made more than 50 presentations published the following paper:  Craft, E. L. (2016, June), When a Traditional Scholarship is Simply Not Enough: Addressing the Digital Divide to Recruit and Motivate Engineering Technology Students through Graduation Paper presented at 2016 ASEE Annual Conference & Exposition, New Orleans, Louisiana. 10.18260/p.27197


Last Modified: 09/09/2019
Modified by: Paul Anderson
